awd_titl_txt: RUI: Embeddings of Discrete Metric Spaces into Banach Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
This project deals with embeddings of finite sets into spaces with well-understood geometry. Such embeddings form a well-established tool in theoretical computer science. Their usefulness can be seen in the following example: Analysis of large sets of data is important in many contexts. Usually data is endowed with a natural distance (degree of dissimilarity) of its elements. One of the useful approaches to analysis of such sets of data is to use some low-distortion embeddings of the set into a space whose structure is well-known, for example into a two-dimensional or three-dimensional space. One can subsequently employ algorithms available in computational geometry and tools from classical mathematics. In some cases one can even visualize the structure of the set, for example, see its clusters.  Another application of embeddings is to construction of approximate algorithms in cases where the algorithms for finding the exact solution of a combinatorial optimization problem are not practical (consume too much time) and we seek not necessarily the optimal solution, but a solution that is close (in some sense) to being optimal. In many cases the best known approximate algorithms are based on metric embeddings. The project aims to deepen understanding in this important area.

The main goal of the proposal is to study embeddings of discrete metric spaces into Banach spaces. The existence of a low-distortion embedding into a plane is rather rare in applications. In many contexts, for example for applications in topology, weaker types of embeddings are useful, and even embeddings into high-dimensional or infinite-dimensional Banach spaces lead to important insights. This project will contribute to the following general question: Find new classes of embeddings of finite and locally finite metric spaces into Banach spaces and find new types of obstructions to such embeddings. The three main directions of the work are: (1) determine to what extent expanders and graphs with large girth resist nontrivially good embeddings; (2) find characterizations of well-known classes of Banach spaces in terms of embeddings; and (3) analyze structures that create obstructions to coarse embeddings of spaces with bounded geometry into a Hilbert space. The project is expected to employ a mixture of methods of geometric functional analysis and graph theory, with some use of methods of probability theory and geometric group theory.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The principal investigator worked on problems in the theories of embeddings of metric spaces into Banach spaces and transportation cost spaces. In the latter, one of the goals is to understand how the cost of combinations of transportation problems depends on costs and the geometry of the partial problems.

The PI organized three research seminars with different groups of undergraduate students. The first seminar's work, which started in Summer 2018 and ended in Spring 2019, resulted in a joint publication with students Seychelle Khan and Mutasim Mim (published in Victor Lomonosov memorial volume, 2020). Both students were accepted to Ph. D. programs in Mathematics.

The mentioned paper with Khan and Mim proved that the transportation cost on a metric space with 2n elements contains a 1-complemented isometric copy of n-dimensional l1. It is a sharp result that strengthens previously known results in this direction.

The second seminar started in Spring 2020 and ended in Fall 2020 (undergraduate students Rainah Khan and Isaac Moorman). This seminar resulted in a research paper that is currently on its way to publication. Isaac Moorman was accepted to a Ph. D. program in Statistics. The third seminar started in Spring 2021 (undergraduate students Kaitlyn Chen, Nicolas Folk, and Yui Takahashi). It is also expected to lead to publishable results. 

The most important results of other work:

With Beata Randrianantoanina proved that non-superreflexive Banach spaces admit a characterization in terms of embeddings of lamplighter groups.

With Sofiya Ostrovska proved a characterization of infinite-dimensional transportation cost spaces containing isometric copies of l1.

In another paper with Sofiya Ostrovska we developed a pasting technique to construct embeddings of infinite locally finite metric spaces from embeddings of their pieces. This technique implies that every locally finite space embeddable into Lp[0,1] with distortion C embeds into lp with distortion C+ε.

With Stephen Dilworth and Denka Kutzarova, we analyzed the structure of transportation cost spaces on different recursive families of graphs and singled out large families of graphs for which the transportation cost spaces are far from l1 of the corresponding dimension.

With Florin Catrina answered a question of Alessio Figalli by proving that there exists and nowhere differentiable isometric embedding of [0,1] into L1[0,1], whose image consists of functions admitting analytic extensions to the complex plane.


Last Modified: 08/29/2021
Modified by: Mikhail Ostrovskii
